bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to W.F. Wilson, January 3, 1942

div1.p: Hench appreciates Wilson's remarks on his article, "Conquerors of Yellow Fever." He discusses fundraising efforts for the Camp Lazear memorial.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to W.F. Wilson, January 3, 1942
div1.opener:
January 3, 1942
Dr. W. F. Wilson
Lake City, Minnesota
My dear Doctor Wilson:
div1.p:
I certainly appreciate your kind remarks on my paper “Conquerors of
Yellow Fever”. I am sending you a more thoroughly illustrated copy of this
paper as it appeared in the Hygeia, thinking you would like to see the colored
print. Should you want one of the large colored prints of this painting, I
am sure you could get it by writing Mr. George Kellogg, 257 Cornelison Avenue,
Jersey City, N. J.

I must confess that I never thought of the idea of having it abstracted
for Readers' Digest. I had no idea that they ever abstracted such articles. I
do appreciate this suggestion greatly and am especially interested in it because
it might arouse some interest which could be converted into some help, financial
or otherwise, in a project I have to memorialize permanently the little building
which still remains and also the site of Camp Lazear. I bought the little build-
ing but the rest of the present site of the former Camp Lazear, would cost
$2500.00 and would cost a few thousand dollars to erect a small but suitable
building to protect and memorialize the little building and camp. I haven't
really started this campaign yet to raise funds but hope to do so when things
get a little more settled. It is possible that if Readers' Digest would publish
the article enough of the readers might be impressed with the idea of memorializing
it to give me some real help.

Let me say that I greatly appreciate your letter. It is such letters
as that which make the hard task of writing seem worthwhile.
div1.closer: Very sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
